column2: locally [ʂɛˈlɛ̌ftɛ] (listen)) is a city and the seat of Skellefteå Municipality in Västerbotten County
column5: 775 inhabitants in 2010. The municipality had approximately 72
column6: 000 inhabitants at the end of 2013.The city is a historically industrial city with mining being a large industry
column7: especially for gold – hence the nickname "Gold Town". Politically it is a Social Democratic stronghold. The city is a well-known ice hockey town
column8: with its main team Skellefteå AIK playing in the Swedish top division: the SHL
column9: which they have won on several occasions.

column1: The city was incorporated in 1845 and grew to its current population size mostly in the 1950s and 1960s
column2: growing only slowly since. It is the second largest city in Västerbotten after Umeå and is located roughly halfway between it and Luleå. The Skellefte River passes through the city and it is located around 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) from the Bothnian Bay open sea. Skellefteå is served by Skellefteå Airport
column3: abbreviated as SKF locally known as Falmark because of the village nearby
column4: also around 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) from the city centre to the south.

column1: The name Skellefteå is recorded to having been spelled as Skelepht in 1327. On Carta marina the name is spelt Skellitta. The origin of the name remains unknown
column2: but is assumed to be of Sami origin.
attempts were made to Christianize Skellefteå. A parish was formed and a church built. However
column3: – for the most part – the entire large Northern Swedish territory of Norrland was not Christianized until several hundred years after the rest of Sweden
column4: and many northern areas such as Skellefteå remained unexplored well past the Middle Ages.

column1: Not before the very end of the 17th century did the indigenous Sami people of Northern Sweden begin turning to Christianity
column2: much due to the efforts by the Northern Swedish superintendent Mathias Steuchius
column3: who worked hard to accomplish this. Several Sami priests were killed for this reason.

column2: the reason for the sudden awakened interest towards Skellefteälven and the surrounding areas were the great northern fishing grounds of salmon.  The increased demand for fish was sparked by a stricter enforcement of the annual month-long fasting by the Catholic Church
column3: whereby meat was substituted by fish.The actual city of Skellefteå is one of the youngest cities of Norrland. It was founded in 1845 by the vicar Nils Nordlander.

column2: Skellefteå evolved to an industrial and mining city and many wooden houses were demolished to make room for brick buildings. Skellefteå is now trying to become a leading city in education with the construction of Floraskolan
column3: a school that mostly focuses on entrepreneurial learning.It will become the home of a massive battery plant made by Northvolt by circa 2023.The largest private employer in Skellefteå is the mining company Boliden AB
column5: 200 employees. The mine's copper ore contains particles of gold
column6: silver and platinum. Skellefteå is still referred to as the "Goldtown".During the 1990s
column8: subsidiaries of Ericsson and Tieto Enator becoming important employers.

column1: The Skellefteå Kraft Grandmaster Chess Cup 1999
column2: one of the strongest all Swedish chess tournaments was won by IGM (International Grandmaster (chess)) Ulf Andersson. The event took place from March 26 – April 4
column4: the final of the two-year World Cup series was held in Skellefteå from August 12 to September 3
column5: 1989. The final sixteen grandmasters participating included three former World Chess Champions Garry Kasparov
column6: Anatoly Karpov and Mikhail Tal. The activities organized around the World Cup final included two performances in Skellefteå of Chess (musical)
column7: with music by Benny Andersson and Björn Ulvaeus of the pop group ABBA.

column1: Skellefteå has a subarctic climate (Dfc) that is borderline continental with mild summers and cold and snowy winters. The climate is somewhat moderated by the Bothnia Bay
column3: ensuring very mild summer temperatures for a coastal area so far north. The surrounding municipality has an all-time high of 33.9 °C (93.0 °F) during the 2014 Swedish heat wave
column4: which is very hot given the latitude and proximity to a major body of water. Although summer highs traditionally averaged just below 20 °C (68 °F) it has been warmer in recent decades.
